title: Multiplicative digital root
summary: In number theory, the multiplicative digital root of a natural number n {\displaystyle n} in a given number base b {\displaystyle b} is found by multiplying the digits of n {\displaystyle n} together, then repeating this operation until only a single-digit remains, which is called the multiplicative digital root of n {\displaystyle n} .[1][2] The multiplicative digital root for the first few positive integers are:
